comments.commentBody: One thing...it's not miserable to know that one,  did it legally and respected the hosts laws. Even their native home countries would not allow such blatant violations of their own borders. IMO an illegal crossing needs to upgraded to a felony. It will send a clear message to those who don't respect or fear our laws regarding unwelcome trespassers. As well as give them pause.

"It would be immoral to extradite them."

How so?

If parents who are here illegally become subject to deportation and they have US citizen children, they should take their children with them, or arrange for the care of these children. Responsibility for these children remains with the illegal immigrant parent(s) -- not the government/taxpayers.

Some illegal immigrants come here conveniently at the time of labor -- fully aware of America's understandable reluctance to enforce a law that might impact young children. This sense of decency should not be used as a bargaining chip by such parent(s). Any negative impact of deportation must fall on their shoulders.

@ Kurfco:

"But, with no path to the taxpayer's wallet, they would be forced to make economic decisions based solely on their own earning potential"

This analysis from the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy (pertaining to North Carolina, home to a large illegal immigrant population)

With fiscal costs and benefits figuring large in the immigration reform debate, a new analysis estimates that undocumented immigrants are already paying $10.6 billion a year in state and local taxes nationwide, including the $253 million they pay each year in North Carolina.

The study also estimates that North Carolina stands to gain $83 million in increased revenue should undocumented immigrants currently in the U.S. be allowed to work here legally.
If the sight of a human being without an artificial layer on makes you cringe, how about you look somewhere else?  Or else just strip down and be one with nature...and your neighbors!

Dear Miss ABC, that is excellent that you explain the role of nature to your daughter, I commend you! Also, do not forget to explain that 99% of meat in restaurants and grocery stores comes from factory farming, which eliminates anything the least bit "natural" from farming. Explain thumping - how they take "disadvantaged" baby piglets, and slam them on concrete floors to "euthanize" them. Explain how they dump cute little male chicks into a macerator, where they are ground up alive. And try, in the interest of educating her, to convey a sense of the number of animals we're doing this to. Yes, suffering and death are part of life.  And we've made sure to add a good portion of suffering - an oceanic portion of suffering - to our plates.

I am not passionate about this question either way.  I lived in El Paso, Texas when the last amnesty was enacted.  It lasted about three weeks.  As soon as they became legal, people began trying to better their situation and new illegals took their place to be exploited by employers.

For those arguing that the illegal immigrants should eventually be allowed U.S. Citizenship, please answer this one question;  "If we allow citizenship to these 11 million illegal people, what are we going to do in 30 years when the next wave of illegal aliens enter our country against our laws?"  When Ronald Reagan gave amnesty in the 1980s to the illegal aliens back then, we were promised that it would solve the problem of illegal immigration.  Over 2 million people were given there green cards and eventual citizenship.   Now it is over 11 million.  So in 30 years we can expect 50 million?  When will it be enough?  My mother had to wait almost a decade to see her mother again because she entered this country legally yet these people who blantantly enter the country against the law are now DEMANDING their rights!  How insulting can they be?  What about Responsibility?   Everyone always talks about Rights but few only remeber the other half of that equation, Responsibilities.  You broke the laws of this country, now take responsibility for youe actions.
Britain did that earlier this year - and the people who were sent home turned around and came right back.
Anyone who broke the law and came in illegally should not be eligible for citizenship.  That should be reserved for those who did it the right way.

Audrey, dear, what are you smoking?
"CItizenship will mean millions of dollars more in tax revenues and home sales and middle educated citizens. Everyone knows that immigrants work the hardest at whatever they do and work the hardest to make sure that their children succeed"- Most of these immigrant work in low end jobs-They dont make enough to pay taxes. In fact the tax breaks they receive ensures that they get more than they pay in. They are also IMMEDIATELY eligible of state/Federal aid in my forms.
Go the Bronx and see who is lining up for official aid there.
Please save for fake empathic for your church.
-and please note that I am a legal immigrant who has obeyed all the laws for the last 9 years and still dont see a Green card in sight.

In many ways, the majority of Americans came here for economic reasons. If they were white, whether they had skills or not, they could simply enter. What is the essential difference between those Americans and Mexicans, who couldn't enter U.S. without special skills, because they were "Hispanics," not European whites, Anglo-saxon stock?

This is pure and simple racial discrimination.

Most Americans know the internment of Japanese Americans during WWII, and are ashamed of it! But close to 2 million Mexican Americans were deported, many of them US born citizens, during the Great Depression, to make room for American workers. Few Americans know this, because the Japanese are way high in the totem pole. Poor mexicans, despite their lighter skin and straight hair, are seen even as beneath African americans. We waged a horrible Civil War, basically to emancipate them, though namely to save the Union.

Agreed and as someone who is against the current immigration reform bill in the U.S. Senate,  I can accept this compromise.   If you entered this country illegally as an adult (18 years and older) then you may become a legal resident, but you will never have the rights of citizenship.  Your children who were born in this country are citizens and the children whom you brought into this country illegally can eventually become citizens like any other legal immigrant.  This in my humble opinion is a fair compromise.

Good write up David.  I am sure for the majority of  the people writing these comments if they trace back their family history many of them will have similar stories to these illegal aliens and how they got to the US.   Maybe the main difference is because the people already here were of the same race or country of origin they were able to bribe their way in instead of via back roads and water.

The past, present and future of the U.S. is inextricably linked with Mexico because of history and geography. As for now...well, 98% of the guns seized in Mexican border towns come from the U.S. The drug trade exists because Americans consume the drugs. I find it kind of hard to fault the average Mexican for giving it a shot here. There's no waiting in line when you're waiting for Godot. I say bienvenido.

Our good-for-nothing politicians and captured media are very clever: They count on our good nature and firm belief that we live in a rich, vast country, ready and able to welcome anyone who would like to join us.

But such is not the case anymore. Just ask former drywallers, carpenters, landscapers and painters whose livelihoods were decimated because we busted our borders wide open. Ask architects, radiologists and computer programmers who were ordered to train their H1B replacements. Query former manufacturing workers whose jobs were outsourced because of our terrible trade agreements, which began our descent to the bottom in the first place. Is there a call center in your state?

Discuss with environmentalists the true carrying capacity of the United States. Then tell our public servants that even though they okayed the latest airline merger because they would be accommodated at their preferred airport so that they need only see our beautiful country from the sky, that we must make our way here.

anyone breaking our laws should be deported
my grandkids were all born in European nations
they do NOT get automatic citizenship

This is ridiculous.  "Progressives" are picking a fight over something that doesn't matter.  99 percent of illegals would be happy to be able to work, come out of the shadows and not have to worry about being deported.   If you want to vote, get in line and come here legally.  The only real issue on citizenship is people who were brought here illegally as children.  If they keep their noses clean and graduate high school let them be citizens; what's the big deal.

There jobs that illegal immigrants have in the US are jobs that most us citizens will never take.  That has been documented many times.  If you have an opinion that is fine, but try to at least base it on accurate facts.
oh please;  the majority of the immigrants to this country have been opportunists for the last 200 years.

@ Retired Law Prof.
I am sorry you think that way. I came to this country in 1989. I have been legal, on annually renewed work visa since then. I graduated from MIT, and have a PhD. I am employed, have two kids born in the U.S., and I do have an immigration attorney. He tells me, there is nothing I can do but wait. Perhaps it is your immigration system, after all?

I am a white middle-aged woman who, similarly, visits Cleveland's nearly all-black Kinsman neighborhood, on a bicycle, and am always made to feel welcome.  The strength, friendliness, and resilience of the majority of inner city residents goes unacknowledged.

I was a child growing up in Scarsdale, N.Y.  Then my family moved to Vermont in the very early 50s.  I moved to the St. Louis Suburbs in the mid to late 1960s.  Divorced and loathing the suburbs I moved to Hyde Park in the mid seventies.  My husband moved there at this time too having come to Wash. U from N.Y.  We met and the rest is history.  We loved north St. Louis.  Monies were pouring into programs that helped support organizations that were assisting in bringing back American cities, albeit slowly.  Then Mr. Reagan became president and put an end to that.  We live and have lived for the last 30 years in the CWE.  You could not drag us away.  It it the most beautiful part of the city.

I'm not angry and I certainly don't feel sorry for myself. I'm simply mystified by the government's apparent double standard here. If the U.S. grants residency, or more, to undocumented immigrants (fine if they do - that's their prerogative), then it seems reasonable to also grant it to people who are here legally - particularly highly qualified people like you.
You need a much better immigration lawyer.

To the person who is angry at not being able to get permanent residency after 5 years of legal stay in the U.S., consider my situation.

I've been in the U.S. for a total of 13+ years. I have earned a B.S. and Ph.D. (latter from an ivy league university); for the B.S. I paid full out-of-state tuition. I now have a job which puts me in the 30%+ tax bracket (happy to pay it, by the way). In fact, I meet and exceed all the criteria for the proposed DREAM legislation, EXCEPT for the fact that I've never been illegally admitted or been without proper legal status.

So yeah, next time you feel sorry about yourself for not being entitled to a green card for staying here for less than five years, get some perspective.

If we really want to follow the law as you outlined,  how about the millions of illegal immigrants that were smuggled here or bribed their way here in the 1900's?  Should their offspring be sent back to Europe?    Have some common sense people;   nothing is perfect;  we need to make the best of an imperfect situation.

Exactly -- THINK how desperate a mother must be to leave her children behind! Try to be a bit more humane.

Also, before I get flamed, just know that I am an entirely legal non-citizen, who would most definitely be hurt by any legislation to legalize undocumented people (because the lines will get much, much longer).
It's not even a misdemeanor, it's a civil violation.

In addition, the whole complaint that they can not go back to visit their friends and family is based on totally twisted logic.  Of course, they can go back any time.  Its just that if they want to come back, they would have to either do it illegally again or wait in line just like every other person who respects our Nation's laws.
